abstracts.cdata!:
The First and Second Petroleum
            Exploration Promotion Projects in Liberia was successful.
            The relationship with the Borrower was usually very good.
            The International Development Association (IDA) did not
            perceive in time, however, the progressive deterioration of
            the Atlantic Resources Limited (ARL)'s services, and as
            a result did not intensify its control of the
            consultant's performance. Furthermore, IDA was not
            vigilant regarding conformity to the Bank's procurement
            guidelines. The Implementation of the project would have
            been improved by hiring a resident independent part-time
            exploration advisor, who could have supervised the
            consultant's selection, technical work, and invoicing,
            by closer IDA supervision. Which could have avoided the
            inadequate implementation of several components of the
            projects, and unduly high costs for the Borrower. If and
            when the World Bank resumes lending to Liberia, it will be
            urgent to assist in privatizing the Liberian Petroleum
            Refining Company (L.P.R.C), and improving the management of
            the petroleum products supply and storage, in order to stop
            the Government's financial deficiency.
